graph title: Annual Caloric Demand including Waste [Food Categories]
description: **All** scenarios affect the indicator Annual Caloric Demand of Food Including Waste by altering demand across eight key food categories. The first four categories in the legend represent animal-based foods, while the last four represent plant-based foods.
plot 1 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[PasMeat]
plot 2 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[CropMeat]
plot 3 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[Dairy]
plot 4 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[Eggs]
plot 5 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[Pulses]
plot 6 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[Grains]
plot 7 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[VegFruits]
plot 8 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[OtherCrops]

description: Explore this further through the **Food Loss and Waste** scenario inputs - to vary the proportion of food lost or wasted either *by Supply Chain* or *by Food Category*. Plant-based foods are often wasted more, especially by consumers, but animal-based food waste, though smaller, causes greater environmental harm because producing it uses more resources.
plot 3 variable: Waste Fraction 100 Percent[Dairy]
plot 4 variable: Waste Fraction 100 Percent[Eggs]

description: The **Diet Change | Population Dynamics** scenario categorises the population into two groups: conventional dieters, who follow traditional diets, and alternative dieters, who adopt non-traditional eating patterns. Individuals can transition from conventional to alternative diets through dietary changes.
plot 1 variable: Total Meat Eaters Per Billion People
plot 3 variable: Total Meat Eaters Per Billion People
plot 4 variable: Total Vegetarians Per Billion People

description: This variable represents the total annual calorie production of the global agricultural system in response to changing food demand. Here, the supply of food is aggregated as plant-based and animal-based products as it helps to emphasise two fundamentally different production systems of crop and livestock farming.
plot 1 variable: Total Supply of Animal Calories in Petacalorie
plot 2 variable: Total Supply of Vegetal Calorie in Petacalorie

description: Annual caloric demand of food including waste across 4 food categories of animal-based food.
plot 1 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[PasMeat]
plot 2 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[CropMeat]
plot 3 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[Dairy]
plot 4 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[Eggs]

description: Annual caloric demand of food including waste across 4 food categories of plant-based food.
plot 1 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[Pulses]
plot 2 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[Grains]
plot 3 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[VegFruits]
plot 4 variable: Annual Caloric Demand inc Waste in Petacalorie[OtherCrops]

description: Total production of animal-derived foods (e.g., beef, pork, poultry). Typically requires more land, water, and feed, contributing to higher environmental impacts.
Total production of plant-derived foods (e.g., cereals, legumes, vegetables, fruits). Generally more land- and resource-efficient than animal-based production.

plot 3 variable: Diet Composition Percentage 100 Percent[Dairy]
plot 4 variable: Diet Composition Percentage 100 Percent[Eggs]

graph title: Caloric Supply per Capita per Day
description: Average daily calorie availability per person from all food sources. Calories provide the energy needed for all bodily functions and activities.
plot 1 variable: Calorie supply per Capita per Day
plot 2 variable: Calorie supply per Capita per Day

graph title: Caloric Supply per Capita per Day [Plant, Animal]
description: Daily calorie availability per person from plant-based and animal-based sources. Key plant sources include cereals (e.g., rice, wheat), while animal-based sources include meat and dairy products.
plot 1 variable: Calorie supply per Capita per Day from Animal Food
plot 2 variable: Calorie supply per Capita per Day from Plant Food

graph title: Protein Supply per Capita per Day
description: Average daily protein availability per person from all food sources. Protein is essential for building and repairing body tissues, enzymes, and hormones.
plot 1 variable: Protein supply per Capita per Day
plot 2 variable: Protein supply per Capita per Day

graph title: Protein Supply per Capita per Day [Plant, Animal]
description: Daily protein availability per person from plant-based and animal-based sources. Major plant sources include legumes and grains; animal-based sources include meat, eggs, and dairy.
plot 1 variable: Protein supply per Capita per Day from Animal Food
plot 2 variable: Protein supply per Capita per Day from Plant Food

graph title: Fat Supply per Capita per Day
description: Average daily fat availability per person from all food sources. Fats are vital for brain function, hormone production, and energy storage.
plot 1 variable: Fat Supply per Capita per Day
plot 2 variable: Fat Supply per Capita per Day

graph title: Fat Supply per Capita per Day [Plant, Animal]
description: Daily fat availability per person from plant-based and animal-based sources. Plant fats mainly come from vegetable oils and nuts; animal-based fats come from meat, butter, and dairy.
plot 1 variable: Fat supply per Capita per Day from Animal Food
plot 2 variable: Fat supply per Capita per Day from Plant Food

description: Annual rate of forest area lost due to land conversion, primarily for agriculture or development. High rates indicate environmental pressure and biodiversity loss.
plot 1 variable: Deforestation as Percentage of Initial Forest Land
plot 2 variable: Deforestation as Percentage of Initial Forest Land

description: Total land area allocated to agriculture and forest uses. Reflects how land is distributed between productive and natural ecosystems.
plot 3 variable: Agricultural Land Per Billion Ha
plot 4 variable: Forest Land Per Billion Ha

description: Average agricultural output per unit of cropland area. A key indicator of land productivity and farming efficiency.
Estimated agricultural land area required based on food demand and production systems. Highlights land pressure under current land use types.
plot 1 variable: Land Allocated for Animal Calories Per Billion ha
plot 2 variable: Land Allocated for Food Crops Per Billion ha
plot 3 variable: Land Allocated for Energy Crops Per Billion ha

description: Estimated land demand broken down by specific land types (e.g., arable, pasture). Useful for evaluating suitability and trade-offs.
plot 1 variable: Total Grassland Needed Per Billion ha

description: Land area required to produce one calorie of food. Lower values indicate more land-efficient food systems.
plot 1 variable: Land Use per Calorie of Food
plot 2 variable: Land Use per Calorie of Food

description: Proportion of total land allocated to different uses (e.g., cropland, pasture, forest). Captures landscape structure and resource allocation.
plot 3 variable: Percentage of Urban and Industrial Land
plot 4 variable: Percentage of Other Land

classification: Emissions in Agriculture, Forestry and Land Use
description: Total greenhouse gas emissions from AFOLU, disaggregated by gas type (CO2, CH4, N2O). Helps identify the dominant gases contributing to emissions.
plot 3 variable: Total CO2 from LULUCF

classification: Emissions in Agriculture, Forestry and Land Use
description: Carbon dioxide emissions from AFOLU, categorized by end-use (e.g., land clearing, biomass burning). Indicates sources linked to land conversion and management.
plot 1 variable: CO2 from Forest Land Change in CO2eq
plot 2 variable: CO2 from Agriculture Land Change in CO2eq

classification: Emissions in Agriculture, Forestry and Land Use
description: Nitrous oxide emissions from AFOLU, categorized by end-use (e.g., fertilizer application, manure management). Reflects emissions from nitrogen-intensive practices.
plot 1 variable: N2O from Agriculture Soils in CO2eq
plot 2 variable: N2O from Livestocks and Manure in CO2eq
plot 3 variable: N2O from Crop Burning in CO2eq

classification: Emissions in Agriculture, Forestry and Land Use
description: Methane emissions from AFOLU, categorized by end-use (e.g., rice cultivation, enteric fermentation). Methane is a potent GHG linked to livestock and wetland crops.
plot 1 variable: CH4 from Livestocks and Manure in CO2eq
plot 2 variable: CH4 from Rice Cultivation in CO2eq
plot 3 variable: CH4 from Crop Burning om CO2eq

classification: Emissions in Agriculture, Forestry and Land Use
description: Aggregate greenhouse gas emissions from the entire AFOLU sector. A key metric for tracking climate impact of land use and agriculture.

classification: Emissions in Agriculture, Forestry and Land Use
description: GHG emissions from AFOLU, broken down by emission source (e.g., livestock, deforestation, soil management). Useful for targeting mitigation strategies.
plot 1 variable: CH4 from Livestocks and Manure in CO2eq
plot 2 variable: CH4 from Rice Cultivation in CO2eq
plot 3 variable: CH4 from Crop Burning om CO2eq
plot 4 variable: N2O from Agriculture Soils in CO2eq
plot 5 variable: N2O from Livestocks and Manure in CO2eq
plot 6 variable: N2O from Crop Burning in CO2eq
plot 7 variable: CO2 from Forest Land Change in CO2eq
plot 8 variable: CO2 from Agriculture Land Change in CO2eq

description: Average global temperature increase compared to preindustrial levels, measured in degrees Celsius.
The total carbon dioxide emissions are the sum of all sources, with AFOLU (Agriculture, Forestry, and Other Land Use) and energy being the two main contributors.

Carbon dioxide emissions come from agriculture, land use, fossil fuels, and renewable sources like biomass. Smaller sources, such as concrete, which contribute less than 10% of total emissions, have been excluded due to the limitations of FeliX.
plot 1 variable: Total CO2 Emissions from Agriculture Per Billion Ton
plot 2 variable: Total CO2 Emissions from Land Use Per Billion Ton
plot 3 variable: Total CO2 Emissions from Fossil Energy Per Billion Ton
plot 4 variable: Total CO2 Emissions from Renewables Per Billion Ton

description: Total synthetic nitrogen applied to agricultural land, excluding organic sources. Synthetic nitrogen is crucial for crop growth, but its excessive use can lead to water pollution, soil degradation, and greenhouse gas emissions.
plot 1 variable: Commercial N application for agriculture Per Million Ton
plot 2 variable: Commercial N application for agriculture Per Million Ton

description: Nitrogen used to produce specific food types (e.g., cereals, legumes, animal feed). Animal-based food production often requires more nitrogen, contributing to higher environmental harm through runoff and emissions.
plot 1 variable: Commercial N application for each category Per Million Ton[PasMeat]
plot 2 variable: Commercial N application for each category Per Million Ton[Pulses]
plot 3 variable: Commercial N application for each category Per Million Ton[Grains]
plot 4 variable: Commercial N application for each category Per Million Ton[VegFruits]
plot 5 variable: Commercial N application for each category Per Million Ton[OtherCrops]

description: Total synthetic phosphorus applied to agricultural land, excluding organic phosphorus. Essential for plant development, but over-application increases the risk of water pollution and algal blooms.
plot 1 variable: Commercial P application for agriculture Per Million Ton
plot 2 variable: Commercial P application for agriculture Per Million Ton

description: Phosphorus applied to grow various food types. Animal-based and feed crops typically demand more phosphorus, intensifying risks of nutrient runoff and water eutrophication.
plot 1 variable: Commercial P application for each category Per Million Ton[PasMeat]
plot 2 variable: Commercial P application for each category Per Million Ton[Pulses]
plot 3 variable: Commercial P application for each category Per Million Ton[Grains]
plot 4 variable: Commercial P application for each category Per Million Ton[VegFruits]
plot 5 variable: Commercial P application for each category Per Million Ton[OtherCrops]

description: Total nitrogen present in the agricultural system, including soil, crops, and external inputs. Reflects nutrient availability, potential surplus, and pollution risks.
Movement of nitrogen through the environment (e.g., leaching, volatilization, runoff). Helps identify major loss pathways and their environmental impacts.
plot 3 variable: Nitrogen from Uptake Rate
plot 4 variable: Nitrogen from Runoff

description: Total phosphorus in the system, including soil stock and added inputs. Important for assessing long-term fertility and risk of overaccumulation.
Pathways of phosphorus movement and loss (e.g., surface runoff, crop uptake). Key for managing efficiency and minimizing pollution.
plot 3 variable: Phosphorus from Uptake Rate
plot 4 variable: Phosphorus from Runoff

description: Crop output per unit of cultivated land. Measures agricultural productivity and land-use efficiency.

Measured in the Mean Species Abundance index, which indicates the average population of species relative to undisturbed ecosystems. 1 represents that the ecosystem is undisturbed, 0 represents that the species are completely lost.

The intactness of biodiversity is impacted by fertilization, biomass production, climate risk and land use change through lowering of the maximum sustainable species population or species carrying capacity.
plot 1 variable: Impact of Fertilizer Consumption on Biodiversity
plot 2 variable: Impact of Biomass Production on Biodiversity
plot 3 variable: Impact of Climate Damage on Biodiversity
plot 4 variable: Impact of Land Use Change on Biodiversity
plot 5 variable: Impact of Fertilizer Consumption on Biodiversity
plot 6 variable: Impact of Biomass Production on Biodiversity
plot 7 variable: Impact of Climate Damage on Biodiversity
plot 8 variable: Impact of Land Use Change on Biodiversity

description: The lost value of the ecosystem is estimated by measuring changes in land area and assessing the economic worth of that land before and after the disturbance.
plot 1 variable: Total Lost Value of Ecosystems Per Billion Dollars
plot 2 variable: Total Lost Value of Ecosystems Per Billion Dollars

description: The lost value of the ecosystem is estimated by measuring changes in land area and assessing the economic worth of that land before and after the disturbance. Different type of land is considered - forest, cropland and other land like woodland and grassland.
plot 1 variable: Total Change in Forest Ecosystem Value Per Billion Dollars
plot 2 variable: Total Change in Cropland Ecosystem Value Per Billion Dollars
plot 3 variable: Total Change in Other Land Ecosystem Value Per Billion Dollars
plot 4 variable: Total Change in Forest Ecosystem Value Per Billion Dollars
plot 5 variable: Total Change in Cropland Ecosystem Value Per Billion Dollars
plot 6 variable: Total Change in Other Land Ecosystem Value Per Billion Dollars

plot 3 variable: Agricultral Land Erosion
plot 4 variable: Agricultural Land Conversion

plot 3 variable: Species Regeneration Rate
plot 4 variable: Negative Species Extinction Rate

description: Scenario 1 vs Scenario 2
Scenario 1 vs Scenario 2
plot 1 variable: Total Lost Value of Ecosystems Per Billion Dollars
plot 2 variable: Total Lost Value of Ecosystems Per Billion Dollars

description: Scenario 1 vs Scenario 2
Scenario 1 vs Scenario 2
plot 1 variable: Total Lost Value of Ecosystems Per Billion Dollars
plot 2 variable: Total Lost Value of Ecosystems Per Billion Dollars

description: Total volume of freshwater withdrawn for food production across all stages. Reflects overall demand on freshwater resources from the food system.
Freshwater used to produce different food categories (e.g., grains, vegetables, meat). Animal-based foods often have higher water footprints, increasing environmental strain.
plot 3 variable: Freshwater Withdrawal for Food[Dairy]
plot 4 variable: Freshwater Withdrawal for Food[Eggs]

description: Amount of freshwater required to produce one calorie of food. A measure of water-use efficiency in the food system. Lower values indicate more efficient diets.
Amount of freshwater required to produce hundred grams of protein. A measure of water-use efficiency in the food system. Lower values indicate more efficient diets.
Total water use for food, adjusted by regional water scarcity. Highlights the true environmental burden by accounting for local freshwater stress.

graph title: Stress-weighted Water Use for Food [Food Categories]
description: Water use by food category, adjusted for local water stress. Animal-based foods tend to contribute disproportionately to water stress, especially in arid regions.
plot 3 variable: "Stress-weighted Water Use for Food"[Dairy]
plot 4 variable: "Stress-weighted Water Use for Food"[Eggs]

description: Water use per calorie, weighted by regional scarcity. Indicates the sustainability of food production under conditions of water scarcity.

graph title: Stress-weighted Water Use Withdrawal per 100g Protein
description: Water use per hundred gram of protein, weighted by regional scarcity. Indicates the sustainability of food production under conditions of water scarcity.

description: Source: AQUASTAT. Annual Freshwater Withdrawals for Agriculture. Year: 2014-2020. Calculation: Annual Freshwater Withdrawals (Agriculture in % Total) * Annual Freshwater Withdrawal (Total in Billion Cubic Meters). Units: Billion Cubic Metres. ID: ER.H2O.FWTL.K3
plot 2 variable: "(data) global agriculture freshwater withdrawal rate AQUASTAT Billion Cubic Metres"

description: Source: FAOSTAT. Land Use. Units: Billion ha. Year: 1990-2014.
